notes: On 17 January 2025, opposition members, including provincial and national MPs, as well as representatives from PSG, SSP, NPS, and PZP: Movement for Reversal, protested by blocking City Hall in Novi Sad. They called for a general strike in support of students occupying their faculties across the country and demanded accountability for the 15 individuals who lost their lives following the collapse of the concrete canopy at the Novi Sad railway station. They additionally demanded the resignation of the mayor of Novi Sad. During the protest, the opposition members displayed a flag featuring the image of a bloody hand, symbolizing the ongoing nationwide protests. Police officers entered City Hall, resulting attacking the protesters. Some opposition members fell down the stairs during the altercation, and a window at City Hall was broken. Gendarmes then attempted to remove the protesters from the plato in front of the building. A local councilor from the movement 'Bravo' was arrested during the protest, while another local councilor from PSG required medical assistance. He reported feeling unwell due to police brutality and claimed that the police had broken a finger of one of his colleagues. Citizens and education workers joined the assembled opposition members to observe a 15-minute moment of silence as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, honoring the victims and calling for accountability for their deaths. During the protest, police officers threatened journalists from Danas, one journalist from TV Nova S was forcibly pulled by his backpack, while another journalist was pushed to the ground.

On 17 January 2025, citizens and students gathered at various locations in Belgrade as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. In front of the Faculty of Law in Belgrade - Palilula, a car driver attempted to go through the crowd. There were no reports on injuries.

In front of the Faculty of Medicine, a man tried to cut one banner with a knife, but was subsequently arrested. Meanwhile, at the Faculty of Law, a car driver attempted to drive through a crowd, pushing and injuring an elderly person with his vehicle. He then took out a metal bat in an attempt to start a fight, but protesters intervened and prevented him from doing so.

On 17 January 2025, between 53.000 and 55.000 students and citizens (according to the Archive of Public Gatherings) gathered to protest in front of the national radio and television station (RTS) in Belgrade - Palilula. They were demanding accountability for the 15 victims who lost their lives when a concrete canopy collapsed at the Novi Sad train station. Their other demands include the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Novi Sad railway station, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during these protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities. The protesters additionally expressed their dissatisfaction with RTS's coverage of the protests, questioning the station's objectivity. An RTS reporter provided live coverage from the protest. Protesters also observed 15 minutes of silence as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, aiming to honor the 15 victims and voice their demands.

On 16 January 2025, students gathered in front of the University Clinical Center (UKC) in Nis to demand support from their professors for their demands. They allege that security personnel physically assaulted them while they were putting up posters at the entrance of the building, a claim denied by the management of the UKC. The students' demands include the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Novi Sad railway station, the immediate release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during these demonstrations, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 16 January 2025, several thousands of students and citizens initially gathered in front of the Faculty of Law in Belgrade - Palilula, where they blocked the Boulevard in front of the faculty for 2 hours, and then proceeded to protest in front of the Supreme Public Prosecutor's Office in Belgrade - Savski Venac prompted by an incident earlier that day when a driver struck one of the students during their gathering in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty. The protesters then marched to the building of the Presidency of the Republic of Serbia in Belgrade - Stari Grad and continued their protest at that location. In two instance, car drivers attempted to go through the crowd near the Slavija Square, but nobody was injured.

On 16 January 2025, students gathered in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade - Palilula as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life. During the protest, a driver struck one of the students who was standing on a walkway. He drove with her on the roof of the car for a few moments after she slipped and fell onto the road. She was urgently admitted to the emergency room and hospitalized. She initially sustained life-threatening injuries, but her state was later stabilized.

On 16 January 2025, students occupied the privately-owned Metropolitan University in Belgrade - Stari Grad, thus joining their peers in a widespread movement demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad. Their demands also include the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 16 January 2025, students and citizens blocked in protest for 15 minutes the Street Svetozara Markovica in Kragujevac as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life. Students additionally expressed their dissatisfaction regarding the pressures they are encountering from their faculty management, professors, and institutions that have been inviting them for 'informative interviews.'

On 16 January 2025, citizens and students gathered in Kragujevac to protest an incident where a fellow student was seriously injured after being struck by a car during the 'Serbia, Stop' gathering in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade.

On 16 January 2025, several hundred of citizens and students gathered in Nis to protest an incident where a fellow student was seriously injured after being struck by a car during the 'Serbia, Stop' gathering in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade.

On 16 January 2025, students blocked the intersection near the Futoska market in Novi Sad to protest an incident where a fellow student was seriously injured after being struck by a car during the 'Serbia, Stop' gathering in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade. The students called for a general strike and earlier that day shouted 'Victory, victory' in front of the court to celebrate the Faculty of Law's management giving up on their plan to hold exams in January in the courthouse, as the faculty is currently occupied by students. Following this, the students marched in protest throughout the city, during which an older woman insulted and physically assaulted them.

On 16 January 2025, university and high school students gathered in Zrenjanin to protest an incident where a fellow student was seriously injured after being struck by a car during the 'Serbia, Stop' gathering in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade.

On 16 January 2025, several masked men entered the home of a gymnasium professor in Cacak and vandalized the property while threatening his wife and children. The professors at the school where he works released a statement expressing their belief that the attack was politically motivated, as he and his colleagues support the ongoing nationwide student occupations. In response to this violent incident, the teachers' council at the school decided to suspend classes entirely as a form of demonstration.

Property destruction: On 16 January 2025, two persons wrote insulting messages and broke the window of the ruling SNS political party's premises on Strazilovska Street in Novi Sad. The suspects for this crime were arrested the following day.

On 16 January 2025, citizens and students gathered in Kraljevo to protest an incident where a fellow student was seriously injured after being struck by a car during the 'Serbia, Stop' gathering in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade.

On 15 January 2025, students gathered in front of the Faculty of Law in Belgrade - Palilula as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been ongoing throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes in honor of the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and to demand accountability for their loss of life. The gathering began with the crowd applauding as a show of support for the students of the Faculty of Law who were attacked and injured during the night of January 13-14 by a mob of six people.

On 15 January 2025, students gathered in Kragujevac as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been ongoing throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes in honor of the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and to demand accountability for their loss of life.

On 15 January 2025, students gathered in Nis as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been ongoing throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes in honor of the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and to demand accountability for their loss of life.

On 14 January 2025, students and citizens gathered in Kragujevac as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life. Protesters also gathered to express concerns that some Faculty of Medical Sciences employees are targeting students by sharing personal data with tabloids to discredit them.

On 14 January 2025, students gathered in front of the Faculty of Medicine in Nis, creating a loud protest to disrupt the management's plans to hold exams. They demanded that the faculty completely suspend all activities, similar to other faculties in Nis.

On 14 January 2025, students occupied the Students Cultural Center (SKC) in Novi Sad, advocating for their demands, including the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during recent protests, and the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during these protests. The students also announced their intention to use this facility to organize cultural programs while occupying the faculty buildings.

On 14 January 2025, high school students and citizens gathered in Valjevo as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life.

On 13 January 2025, students gathered in Nis to observe 15 minutes of silence just before midnight - coinciding with the celebration of Serbian Orthodox New Year's Eve. This event was part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign that has been ongoing across the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes. This gesture honors the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demands accountability for the loss of their lives.

On 13 January 2025, students gathered in Novi Sad to observe 15 minutes of silence just before midnight - coinciding with the celebration of Serbian Orthodox New Year's Eve. This event was part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign that has been ongoing across the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes. This gesture honors the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demands accountability for the loss of their lives.

On 13 January 2025, students, parents and teachers organized by their union protested in front of the Aviation Academy in Belgrade - Stari Grad against the replacement of the current director with a new one allegedly affiliated with the governing political party and has no prior experience in aviation. As a result of the situation, some members of the management and teachers have already resigned in protest, putting the school's operations at risk since they hold the necessary certifications to issue aviation licenses.

Around 13 January 2025 (between 13 - 14 January), a group of six men attacked students who were occupying the Faculty of Law in Belgrade - Palilula. They hurled bottles at the students and physically assaulted them, resulting in injuries to seven students. The attackers identified themselves as supporters of the President of Serbia and the ruling political party. They also attempted to urinate on the Faculty building but were stopped by the students. So far, four individuals have been detained in connection with this incident.

On 12 January 2025, 28000 students and citizens (according to the Archive of Public Gatherings) protested in front of the Constitutional Court in Belgrade - Palilula demanding accountability for 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at the Novi Sad train station. Additionally, they called for the fulfilment of student demands as students occupied faculties across the country and expressed concern over the human rights violations faced by protesters and students in recent times. Students who are occupying their faculties demand the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Novi Sad railway station, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during these protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities. The protesters began by observing 15 minutes of silence as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, with an aim to honor the 15 victims and voice their demands. Some members of extreme-right organizations attended the gathering, holding flags with nationalist messages. However, students later publicly condemned their presence, stating that these views do not align with their values or goals. On the same day, university and high school students, along with citizens gathered in Belgrade - Zemun as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign.

On 12 January 2025, between 1.700 and 1.800 citizens, students, and education workers (according to the Archive of Public Gatherings) blocked in protest two crossroads in Nis, and then marched to the building of the University of Nis. They demanded accountability for the loss of 15 lives following the canopy collapse at the Novi Sad train station, ultimately blaming corruption for this tragic event. The protesters began their gathering by observing 15 minutes of silence as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, with an aim to honor the 15 victims and voice their demands.

On 11 January 2025, between 3.500 and 4.000 citizens, university and high school students (according to the Archive of Public Gatherings) gathered in Kragujevac as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life.

On 11 January 2025, around 2000 citizens and students (according to the Archive of Public Gatherings) protested in front of the building of the Security Intelligence Agency (BIA) in Novi Sad under the slogan 'we came for a friendly chat' referring to the numerous 'friendly chats' that the protesters, students, and organizers had been invited to by this agency in recent period.

On 10 January 2025, multiple protest actions took place throughout Belgrade. Students initially gathered in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade - Vracar, observing 15 minutes of silence as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, and then sang the song 'Serbia' by poet Oskar Davico. They then marched towards the Palace of Justice in Belgrade - Savski Venac, where the trial of those accused of attacking students during a previous protest at the Faculty of Dramatic Arts (FDU) was set to begin. A crowd of between 7000 and 7200 students and citizens (according to the Archive of Public Gatherings) then blocked the Mostarska Petlja and Gazela Bridge in Belgrade - Savski Venac in protest, demanding accountability for the loss of 15 lives following the collapse of a concrete canopy at the train station in Novi Sad, ultimately blaming corruption for this tragic event.

On 10 January 2025, several tens of high school students and citizens gathered in Cacak as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life.

The protesters began by observing 15 minutes of silence as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, with an aim to honor the 15 victims and voice their demands.

Some car drivers attempted to go through the crowd at several different locations throughout the city, but were stopped by citizens. Nobody was injured. A women's rights activist from 'Women for Change' ('Zene za promenu') observed a moment of silence lasting 16 minutes at Liberty Square, paying tribute to Novi Sad's victims, but also for a femicide victim who was recently murdered in Srbobran.

On 3 January 2025, citizens gathered in Aleksandrovac to participate in a modified version of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, this time not only honoring the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy, but also two people who were killed on December 31 in Arilje, and 12 people who fell victims of a mass shooting on January 1 in Cetinje. They also demanded to provide statements to the police, explaining that the man was trying to protect them.

On 3 January 2025, citizens along with veterans of the 63rd Parachute Brigade gathered in Kraljevo to participate in a modified version of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, this time not only honoring the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy, but also two people who were killed on December 31 in Arilje, and 12 people who fell victims of a mass shooting on January 1 in Cetinje. On 2 January 2025, several hundred students and citizens gathered in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade - Vracar to participate in a modified version of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. Instead of pausing their activities for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy following a collapse of a concrete canopy at the city's train station, they observed 29 minutes of silence, to also honor two people who were killed on December 31 in Arilje, and 12 people who fell victims of a mass shooting on January 1 in Cetinje. The aim of the campaign is to demand accountability for their loss of life.

On 31 December 2024, between 17.000 and 18.000 citizens and students (according to the Archive of Public Gathering) gathered near the Republic Square in Belgrade - Stari Grad to observe 15 minutes of silence just before midnight, as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. With this action, protesters wanted to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at the Novi Sad train station, and call for accountability regarding this tragedy. Similar actions on New Year's Eve were held in two other cities, Novi Sad and Nis. Currently, over 50 faculties across four universities are closed and occupied by students. Their demands include the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Novi Sad railway station, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during these protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 31 December 2024, citizens and students gathered in Kragujevac to observe 16 minutes of silence just before midnight, as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. With this action, protesters wanted to call for accountability and honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at the Novi Sad train station, but also to honor a victim from school shooting in Croatia. Currently, over 50 faculties across four universities are closed and occupied by students. Their demands include the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Novi Sad railway station, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during these protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 31 December 2024, citizens and students gathered in Nis to observe 15 minutes of silence just before midnight, as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. With this action, protesters wanted to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at the Novi Sad train station, and call for accountability regarding this tragedy. Currently, over 50 faculties across four universities are closed and occupied by students. Their demands include the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Novi Sad railway station, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during these protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

notes: On 31 December 2024, between 4.500 and 6.000 citizens and students (according to the Archive of Public Gatherings), along with an MP and a vice-president of the SSP, gathered in Novi Sad to observe 15 minutes of silence just before midnight, as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. With this action, protesters wanted to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at the Novi Sad train station, and call for accountability regarding this tragedy. Currently, over 50 faculties across four universities are closed and occupied by students. Their demands include the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Novi Sad railway station, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during these protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 30 December 2024, students gathered in front of the City Assembly in Novi Sad demanding to attend a session to discuss their demands, and call for the dismissal of the Mayor of Novi Sad and the President of the City Assembly. Their demands include the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Novi Sad railway station, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during these protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities. After being denied entry to the building, students symbolically held their own session and observed 15 minutes of silence as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement, which has been occurring throughout the country since November 22, calls for participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their deaths. There was some pushing between police officers and opposition councilors who also attempted to enter the building. However, after being turned away, the councilors joined the students in their protest. Meanwhile, the Higher Public Prosecutor's Office filed an indictment against 13 individuals, including the former Minister of Transport and the former director of Serbian Railway Infrastructure, charging them with responsibility for the collapse of the canopy at the Novi Sad Railway Station. Students are dissatisfied with the indictment, arguing that it does not hold all responsible parties accountable, nor does it address the issue of corruption, which they believe is the primary reason for the canopy's collapse.

On 30 December 2024, citizens and students gathered at various locations in Belgrade as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life. Near Kalemegdan Fortress in Belgrade-Stari Grad, a driver drove through the crowd, injuring one student. Another incident occurred in front of the Faculty of Veterinary, Medicine and Dentistry in Belgrade-Savski Venac, where a driver attempted to drive through the gathered crowd. Students from several faculties have reported receiving threats from unknown numbers on their personal phones.

On 29 December 2024, farmers blocked the road in protest in Badovinci, demanding the resignation of the Minister of Agriculture, the Prime Minister of Serbia, and the Chairman of the Parliamentary Committee on Agriculture, citing failure to fulfill agreed-upon obligations, including benefits and subsidies for agricultural workers.

On 29 December 2024, citizens and students gathered in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade - Vracar as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life.

On 29 December 2024, farmers blocked the road in protest in Loznica, demanding the resignation of the Minister of Agriculture, the Prime Minister of Serbia, and the Chairman of the Parliamentary Committee on Agriculture, citing failure to fulfill agreed-upon obligations, including benefits and subsidies for agricultural workers.

On 29 December 2024, citizens blocked Dositejeva Street in Kraljevo to protest the authorities' inadequate response to preventing traffic accidents in the area. They highlighted the absence of speed bumps that could enhance road safety. This protest was triggered by a recent incident in which two boys were hit and injured by a car.

On 28 December 2024, former employees of Mei Ta Company gathered to protest in front of the company's seat in Baric. A total of 296 employees were suddenly terminated without prior notice or explanation. The employees suspect that the reason for their dismissal is the company's plans to replace them with a cheaper labor force from India.

On 28 December 2024, citizens and students gathered in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade - Palilula as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life. Additionally, artists, musicians, and actors have shown massive support for the protests by raising their hands while wearing red gloves after their shows.

On 28 December 2024, a large number of citizens, high school students, parents, and teachers gathered in front of the 'Jovan Jovanovic Zmaj' high school in Novi Sad to hold a public class and demand an apology from their director. This demand came after the director issued a statement in which he apologized to the Prime Minister for the pupils who had gathered in front of the school to honor the victims of a recent tragedy in Novi Sad when 15 people lost their lives following the collapse of a concrete canopy at the city's train station. In his statement, he claimed that the students were being used for political purposes.

On 27 December 2024, an orchestra conductor was physically assaulted by her co-worker at the National Theater in Belgrade - Stari Grad, and had to be transferred to the ER due to the injuries she sustained. The incident occurred right after the performance of the opera 'Cinderella' when the conductor came out on stage showing support to the ongoing nation-wide protests demanding accountability for the tragedy in Novi Sad in which 15 people lost their lives. She did so by raising a hand wearing a red glove representing 'bloody hands' - a main symbol of these protests. Additionally, the opera singer portraying Cinderella, who is also an MP of the governing SNS political party, refused to shake her hand on stage.

On 27 December 2024, citizens gathered at various locations in Belgrade as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, including in front of the Faculty of Economy in Belgrade - Savski Venac where a driver drove through the crowd, hitting a student and throwing him onto the car's hood. The injured student was transferred to the emergency room for treatment. The 'Serbia, Stop' campaign has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life.

After the 15 minutes of silence, they marched in protest to block the Bridge of Youth.

On 27 December 2024, citizens and students, along with representatives from the Professional Union JMU RTV (Strukovni Sindikat JMU RTV), protested in front of the Radio-Television of Vojvodina (RTV) building in Novi Sad. The protesters also called for the resignation of RTV's Editor-in-Chief. On the same day, citizens, high school and university students also gathered at various locations in Novi Sad as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life.

The protesters in Valjevo also aimed to show support for their colleague who was dismissed from the position of head of the First Surgical Clinic at the University Hospital for publicly criticizing the Minister of Health and advocating for students' demands to be met.

This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life.

On 26 December 2024, citizens, university and high school students, members of the opposition, and activists from the Association 'NOT to Take a Deep Breath' (Da (NE) Disemo Duboko) staged a protest in Uzice titled 'Burned Out' ('Dogorelo'). The protest aimed to demand accountability for the collapse of a canopy at the Novi Sad train station on November 1, which resulted in the deaths of 15 people. Additionally, the protesters expressed their dissatisfaction with the garbage disposal operations at the Duboko wild landfill in their city. To honor the 15 victims, the protesters observed 15 minutes of silence as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign.

On 25 December 2024, students marched in protest to the Supreme Public Prosecutor's Office in Belgrade - Savski Venac where they symbolically left 1000 identical letters addressed to the Public Prosecutor asking her to 'start doing her job'. The protesters demand accountability for the collapse of a canopy at the Novi Sad train station that resulted in the deaths of 15 people. Their demands included the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Novi Sad Railway Station, the dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, and the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the demonstrations. The gathering began with a 15-minute moment of silence to honor the 15 victims, as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign that has been ongoing across the country since November 22. Activists from the initiative 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje') together with opposition members also gathered as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign in front of the City Hall in Belgrade - Stari Grad, where they spilled the red paint on the asphalt symbolizing the blood on the authorities' hands. The activists also attempted to enter the City Assembly session, but security officers prevented them by pushing them away from the entrance. On the same day, one of the students involved in the protests was being invited for 'a friendly chat' by the Security Intelligence Agency.

On 25 December 2024, postal workers, along with students, protested in front of the Main Post Office in Belgrade - Stari Grad demanding a 25% increase in salaries, improved working conditions, better employment contracts, measures to prevent workplace abuse, a new set of regulations, and a solidarity assistance payment of 50,000 dinars.

On 25 December 2024, several tens of high school and university students, along with some professors and citizens, gathered in Cacak as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life.

On 25 December 2024, citizens and high school students gathered in Valjevo as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life.

On 24 December 2024, high school students occupied the 'Bora Stankovic' Gymnasium and '9. maj' Gymnasium in Nis, meaning that as a result all four high schools in the city joined the students' occupations. These pupils are advocating for students' demands to be met, including the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, and the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests.

On 23 December 2024, around 50 health workers gathered in front of the Health Center in Loznica to express support for the students who are occupying faculties across the country, demanding among else the accountability over the collapse of a canopy at the Novi Sad train station that killed 15 people. Additionally, protesters were calling for better salaries and working conditions.

On 23 December 2024, students and citizens gathered in Nis as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life. On the same day, high school students occupied the First Gymnasium 'Stevan Sremac' in Nis, thus joining the country-wide students' occupations demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 23 December 2024, university and high school students gathered in Novi Sad as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This movement has been taking place throughout the country since November 22, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life.

On 23 December 2024, citizens and high school students gathered in Valjevo as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. Their demands also include the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 22 December 2024, between 100.000 and 102.000 people (according to the Archive of Public Gatherings), including citizens, students, farmers, actors, education workers, and athletes marched in protest from various locations in Belgrade, gathering finally at Slavija Square in Belgrade - Vracar, demanding government accountability over the November 1 collapse of a canopy at the Novi Sad train station that killed 15 people. The protest started with a 15-minute silence to commemorate the victims. A group of students went to the National Assembly in Belgrade - Stari Grad to block the traffic, when a taxi driver struck and injured a protester with his car, for which he had to be transferred to the ER. Taxi driver fled the scene, but was later arrested. Ahead of the protest an activist from 'Ne damo Jadar' climbed onto a tractor, but a group of men in black jackets violently removed him, while another activist from 'Ne damo Jadar' was detained for allegedly insulting police officers.
On 22 December 2024, several tens of health workers protested in Kragujevac to demand accountability over the November 1 collapse of a canopy at the Novi Sad train station that killed 15 people.

On 22 December 2024, around 7.000 citizens, students, and health workers protested in Nis to demand accountability over the November 1 collapse of a canopy at the Novi Sad train station that killed 15 people. A verbal confrontation between a man and a protesters escalated to a physical altercation, but they were quickly separated by other protesters.

On 21 December 2024, several hundred students gathered in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade - Vracar, at 11:52 AM to block the Boulevard as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This initiative aims to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and to demand accountability for their loss of life. This particular action lasted for 16 minutes, as it also sought to commemorate the victim of a school stabbing in Zagreb that occurred the day before.
On 21 December 2024, activists from 'Start-Change' movement gathered in front of the fortress in Nis to protest against Rio Tinto company and lithium mining in Serbia.

assoc_actor_2: Government of Serbia (2017-); SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice
notes: On 20 December 2024, an MP who also serves as the president of the SSP, along with another member of the party, were physically assaulted in Belgrade by a group of approximately 10 members of the ruling SNS political party. This group included the city's secretary for investments, who was putting up posters with messages labelling the SSP president as a thief. The confrontation began as a verbal dispute and escalated into a physical altercation. During the incident, the SSP president sustained injuries to his head and ankle, while the other SSP member suffered kicks to his back and head, resulting in multiple hematomas. Both of them were admitted to the Emergency Center for treatment. In contrast, officials from the SNS party claim that the SSP members initiated the conflict, stating that one of their members was also admitted to the ER and diagnosed with a concussion.

assoc_actor_1: NPS: People's Movement of Serbia; Students (Serbia); Teachers (Serbia)
notes: On 17 December 2024, students protested in front of the Vojvodina Assembly during its session, calling for students' demands and the question around accountability for the death of 15 people following the collapse at Novi Sad's train station to be on the agenda. During the Assembly session, opposition members insisted on discussing the dismissal of both the Assembly's President and the President of Vojvodina's Government. During the session, a member of the Vojvodina's Assembly from NPS was hit by a man in his face, as media reported probably a member of the Assembly's security. After the opposition's proposal was rejected, they left the session and joined the protesting students outside. A member of the SRS who wanted to pass through the crowd of protesters pushed away one woman and assaulted a journalist from N1TV by hitting her microphone. After the session concluded, students prevented a member of the PUPS from exiting the building. Following this, they proceeded to the 'Jovan Jovanovic Zmaj' Gymnasium to join high school students, citizens, and professors who had gathered for the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This initiative encouraged participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes in honor of the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and to demand accountability for their deaths. Citizens also assembled in various locations throughout Novi Sad as part of this campaign.

On 17 December 2024, citizens gathered in various locations throughout Belgrade as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. Participants were encouraged to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and to demand accountability for their loss of life. Students also hung 15 red balloons in front of the Palace of Serbia in Belgrade - Novi Beograd, coinciding with a government session attended by the Serbian President. On the same day, high school students occupied the Zemun Gymnasium in Belgrade - Zemun, joining the wider movement of students' occupations.

On 17 December 2024, taxi drivers protested in front of the Police Administration building in Belgrade - Palilula because one of their colleagues was severely beaten by a group of people. Since this was not the first instance of such assaults, the protesters demanded a meeting with police officials to discuss the issues they are facing on the streets, particularly in the Batajnica neighborhood.

notes: On 17 December 2024, students, citizens, and activists of the initiative 'Ne damo Jadar' and SEOS protested in front of the Hotel Hilton in Belgrade - Stari Grad where the mining company Rio Tinto was having a party in order to protest against lithium mining in Serbia.

On 17 December 2024, around 1000 high school students, their parents and professors gathered in Cacak as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life. Part of the pupils also occupied their high schools to advocate for students' demands to be met, including the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 17 December 2024, farmers blocked the road in Glusci to demand the resignation of the Minister of Agriculture, citing failure to fulfill agreed-upon obligations. They also called for the resignation of the Prime Minister of Serbia, who had guaranteed that the agreement would be honored.

On 17 December 2024, students at the Faculty of Economy in Kragujevac joined the widespread movement of students' occupation, effectively marking the occupation of the entire University of Kragujevac. Students demand the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities. Currently, more than 50 faculties across four universities are closed and occupied by students. On this day, students also gathered in Kragujevac to honor the victims for 15 minutes as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign.

On 17 December 2024, citizens gathered in various locations in Nis as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life. Students protested in front of the university building while waiting for the arrival of the Minister of Education. After her arrival was delayed, they marched to the City Assembly, where they demanded an apology from the SNS councilor who had publicly insulted them by claiming they were paid to protest and linking them to the Prime Minister of Kosovo. Students also honored Novi Sad's victims by keeping 15 minutes of silence in front of the Faculty of Medicine in Nis, and afterwards occupied the faculty building, demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 17 December 2024, high school students occupied the Gymnasium in Obrenovac, advocating for students' demands to be met, including the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 17 December 2024, high school students and their professors occupied the Gymnasium in Valjevo, advocating for students' demands to be met, including the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities. Pupils also gathered in front of their school for 15 minutes to honor the Novi Sad's victims, and announced that they will gather like that every day.

On 17 December 2024, farmers along with members of the organization 'We won't give away Jadar' ('Ne damo Jadar') blocked the road in Zavlaka to demand the resignation of the Minister of Agriculture, citing failure to fulfill agreed-upon obligations. They also called for the resignation of the Prime Minister of Serbia, who had guaranteed that the agreement would be honored, and of the President of the Parliamentary Committee for Agriculture.

On 17 December 2024, high school students occupied the Gymnasium in Zrenjanin advocating for students' demands to be met, including the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 17 December 2024, citizens, opposition members, and high school students gathered in front of the City's Assembly in Kraljevo as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, encouraging participants to pause their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for their loss of life.

On 16 December 2024, citizens and students held 15-minute moment of silence in various locations in Belgrade to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at Novi Sad's train station, and demand accountability for their death. High school students occupied or suspended classes in their schools throughout Belgrade in order to support the broader student movement who have been occupying their academic institutions across the country. Among these schools are - the 1st, 3rd, 8th, 9th, 10th, and 14th Gymnasium, Philological High School, Sports' Gymnasium, Gymnasium in Zemun, and Gymnasium 'St. Sava'. Students' demands include the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 16 December 2024, citizens held a 15-minute moment of silence as a part of 'Serbia, stop' campaign in Cacak to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at Novi Sad's train station, and demand accountability for their death.

On 16 December 2024, high school students partially occupied the 'Takovski ustanak' Gymnasium in Gornji Milanovac advocating for students' demands to be met, including the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities. On the same day, citizens held a 15-minute moment of silence in Cacak to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at Novi Sad's train station, and demand accountability for their death.

On 16 December 2024, students at the Faculties of Law, Medical and Engineering Sciences in Kragujevac joined the widespread movement of students' occupation. Students demand the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 16 December 2024, high school students occupied the 'Jovan Jovanovic Zmaj' Gymnasium in Novi Sad, demanding that the school withdraw a statement in which the director and school board apologized to the Prime Minister for the students who had gathered in front of the school to honor the victims of Novi Sad. The statement claimed that the students were being used for political purposes. Additionally, they demanded that the school officially supports students' demands who have been occupying their faculties. Students at the Technical College in Novi Sad also joined the widespread movement of students' occupation, demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities. On 16 December 2024, students and their professors held a 15-minute moment of silence in front of the Faculty of Security in Belgrade - Vozdovac as part of 'Serbia, stop' campaign to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at Novi Sad's train station, and demand accountability for their death. During the gathering, a driver attempted to break through, though nobody was injured.

On 15 December 2024, citizens held a 15-minute moment of silence in various locations as part of 'Serbia, stop' campaign in Belgrade to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at Novi Sad's train station, and demand accountability for their death.

On 15 December 2024, several thousand of citizens, university and high school students organized by the groups 'Svice' and 'Stav' gathered in front of the Rectorate building in Novi Sad to keep 15 minutes of silence to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at Novi Sad's train station, and afterwards call for demands of students who have been occupying academic institutions across the country to be addressed. Their demands include the release and dismissal of charges against individuals arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against those who attacked students during the demonstrations, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 15 December 2024, citizens held 15-minute moment of silence in front of the Faculty of Agriculture in Belgrade - Zemun as part of 'Serbia, Stop' campaign to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at Novi Sad's train station, and demand accountability for their death. During the gathering, a driver attempted to break through, resulting in some protesters being thrown onto his car's hood. One protester, who was struck, jumped onto the car and broke the windshield.

On 14 December 2024, several hundred high school students and citizens, organized by the group 'Soma' protested at Liberty Square in Novi Sad, demanding accountability for 15 people who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at the Novi Sad train station. On 14 December 2024, citizens and students held 15-minute moment of silence in front of the Faculty of Sports and Physical Education in Belgrade - Cukarica as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy collapsed at Novi Sad's train station, and demand accountability for their death. Near Futoska Pijaca, four men drove a car into the protesters, injuring several people, including the son of a 'Bravo' activist. This incident sparked a confrontation between the protesters and the four men. The attackers were later arrested, one of whom was an off-duty police officer.

notes: On 13 December 2024, agricultural workers, accompanied by an MP from NPS, and a councilor from the NLS, blocked the Ibarska highway in Adrani using their tractors. On 12 December 2024, several tens of thousands students gathered in front of RTS (Radio Television Serbia) in Belgrade - Palilula to block the road and create noise during the prime-time news broadcast. Their goal was to draw attention to the fact that national television RTS was not covering enough nor fairly their activities, but accused them of being paid to block their faculties. Additionally, students gathered at several other locations to honor the victims of the Novi Sad's tragedy. This included a gathering in front of the Technical Faculties in Belgrade - Vracar, where the students already announced daily assemblies at 11:52, the exact time when the concrete canopy collapsed.

On 12 December 2024, more than 100 members of the Trade Union of the Serbian Administration (Sindikat uprave Srbije) marched in protest from the National Assembly to the Serbian government building in Belgrade - Savski Venac, demanding salary increases for employees in public institutions, social insurance agencies, and local self-government units.
On 12 December 2024, several tens of students gathered in front of the Technical Faculty in Cacak to honor 15 victims of Novi Sad's tragedy.

On 12 December 2024, high school students occupied the First Gymnasium in Kragujevac, marking the first high school to join the students' occupations. These pupils also gathered in front of their school, advocating for students' demands to be met, including the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 12 December 2024, students from the Faculty of Occupational Safety and the Faculty of Sports and Physical Education gathered in front of their institutions in Nis to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy. They observed a moment of silence for 15 minutes, after which they entered the buildings to discuss the possibility of joining the large student occupations.

On 12 December 2024, students occupied the Rectorate building, as well as the Faculty of Sport and Physical Education in Novi Sad, effectively marking the occupation of the entire University of Novi Sad. Students demand the resignation of the Novi Sad's rector, publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against the individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities. On the same day, students also gathered in front of their faculties, blocking roads and holding a 15-minute silence to honor the victims.

On 12 December 2024, students occupied the Faculty of Pedagogy in Sombor, thus joining their peers in a widespread movement demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad. Their demands also included the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 12 December 2024, students gathered in front of the Faculty of Economy in Subotica to honor 15 victims of Novi Sad's tragedy, holding banners and messages to support their demands, including the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

notes: On 12 December 2024, members of the opposition, including representatives from the Start-Change movement, the SSP, the NPS, a local councilor from the 'Bravo' movement, and an MP from DS, staged a protest in front of the Police Administration building in Novi Sad. They demanded accountability for the police's beating of a pensioner who participated in the protests in Novi Sad on 21 November, and called for the resignation of the Head of the Novi Sad Police. The police officers forcibly pushed protesters away from the entrance. During the pushing, several journalists fell to the ground.

On 12 December 2024, high school students gathered in the school's yard in Kraljevo to show solidarity with students who have been occupying faculties across the country, demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against the individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 11 December 2024, activists from the initiative 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje'), first blocked the intersection of roads in Belgrade - Savski Venac leading to the controversial luxury residential neighborhood known as Belgrade Waterfront, protesting against the closure and removal of the Old Sava Bridge. Afterwards, they joined students who had gathered in front of the Presidency in Belgrade (coded separately).

On 11 December 2024, citizens and activists of the initiative 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje') blocked the traffic in the contested luxury residential neighborhood Belgrade Waterfront in Belgrade - Savski Venac to protest against the removal of the Old Sava Bridge, and afterwards joined the protesters in front of the Presidency building in Belgrade - Stari Grad (coded separately).

On 11 December 2024, students first gathered along with their professors in front of the Faculty of Mathematics in Kragujevac, and then occupied this faculty, joining their peers in a widespread movement, demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 11 December 2024, several hundred students first gathered in front of the Faculty of Electrical Engineering in Nis to honor the victims of the Novi Sad tragedy for 15 minutes and then occupied the faculty, joining their peers in a widespread movement, demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 11 December 2024, students occupied the Faculties of Agriculture and Medicine, as well as the Higher Business School in Novi Sad. They joined their peers in a widespread movement demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad. Their demands also included the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities. On the same day, employees, teachers, and students of the University of Novi Sad gathered in front of the Rectorate building to honor the victims and demand accountability for those responsible for the tragedy and called for the resignation of the rector for not supporting the students' protests.

On 11 December 2024, students gathered for the second consecutive day in front of the Faculty of Economics in Subotica to honor the victims of the Novi Sad tragedy. They observed a 15-minute moment of silence and called for accountability from those responsible for the deaths.

On 11 December 2024, students and activists of the organizations 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje') and 'Fight' ('Borba') gathered at various locations in Belgrade to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when a concrete canopy collapsed at the train station in Novi Sad. They also aimed to draw attention to their demands, leading to the occupation of faculties across the country. In Kneza Milosa Street, a driver attempted to pass through the crowd but was stopped. Lawyers joined students who gathered in front of the Faculty of Law in Belgrade - Palilula. Several thousand students and activists also gathered in front of the Presidency building in Belgrade - Stari Grad during a public address by the Serbian President, which was broadcast live on national television. They were loud and intentionally disrupted his speech. During the address, the President promised that all documentation related to the reconstruction process of the train station in Novi Sad would be made public. After he finished speaking, the students blocked the building's exit, but police dispersed the crowd with shields, allowing the President to leave the building safely. Currently, approximately 40 faculties across four universities in Serbia remain closed and occupied by students.

On 10 December 2024, students occupied the Faculties of Teacher Education and Fine Arts in Belgrade, as part of a widespread movement involving the occupation of faculty and university buildings, demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against the individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities. On the same day, students gathered, and in some cases blocked roads at several locations in Belgrade, including Knez Mihailova Street, the intersection of Knez Milosa Street and Srpskih Vladara, and in front of the Electrotechnical Faculty (coded separately) to draw attention to their demands.

On 10 December 2024, students from the Dramatic Arts gathered in front of the Municipal Assembly in Belgrade - Novi Beograd with an aim to attend a session where councilors were discussing the potential dismissal of a fellow councilor from the ruling SNS party. This councilor had been publicly identified by the media as one of the attackers who physically assaulted the Drama students during their protest on 22 November. The students were not permitted to attend the session, leading them to stage a protest outside the municipality's building alongside members of opposition political parties. Ultimately, the local councilors decided not to dismiss the councilor in question.

assoc_actor_1: SRCE: Serbia Centre; SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice
notes: On 10 December 2024, around 20 citizens and opposition members from the SSP and SRCE protested in front of the Metropol Hotel in Belgrade - Vracar, prior to a conference discussing corruption. They later entered the conference, accusing the organizers of hypocrisy because the Agency for the Fight against Corruption had awarded certificates of appreciation to government representatives for their efforts in combating corruption during the event. The Minister of Foreign Affairs left the conference by exiting through the back door.

On 10 December 2024, university students and high school students, along with their professors, gathered in Kragujevac to honor 15 victims who lost their lives when a concrete canopy collapsed at the Novi Sad train station and express support for the students who are occupying faculties across the country.

On 9 December 2024, students occupied the Faculties of Contemporary Arts, Security and Agriculture in Belgrade as part of a larger movement demanding the release of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad. On 9 December 2024, students occupied the Faculty of Mathematics in Nis, joining their peers in a widespread movement demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad. The students' demands are consistent with those of their peers and include the following: the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against individuals who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities.

On 8 December 2024, citizens, organized by the groups 'Svice' and 'Stav', marched in protest from the City Assembly to the Students' City in Novi Sad demanding accountability for a recent tragic event in which 15 people lost their lives due to the collapse of a concrete canopy at the railway station in Novi Sad. Protesters painted the ground in front of the City Assembly red, symbolizing the blood on the authorities' hands. This protest aimed to draw attention to the demands of students who have been occupying their faculties in response to a tragic event in Novi Sad, where 15 people lost their lives due to the collapse of a concrete canopy at the train station.

On 6 December 2024, citizens and students gathered in various locations throughout Belgrade as part of the 'Serbia, stop' campaign which has been taking place every Friday since November 22 and encourages participants to halt their activities and block roads for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy, demanding accountability for their loss of life.

On 6 December 2024, students occupied Faculties of Economy and Organizational Sciences, as well as the Electrotechnical Faculty in Belgrade, thus joining their peers in a widespread movement, deciding to occupy their faculty buildings, demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against the individuals who attacked students during the protests. This action was part of a nationwide wave of protests, during which students occupied their faculties, all sharing the same demands, announcing that the occupation would continue until these demands were met. Around 300 students and 30 professors also gathered in front of the Faculty of Economy at 11:52 as part of the 'Serbia, stop' campaign. Students of the Electrotechnical faculty announced that they would block the Boulevard in front of their institution every day at 11:52 for 15 minutes.

On 6 December 2024, members of the Philharmonic Orchestra protested and blocked the road with their bodies in front of their hall in Belgrade - Stari Grad, as part of the 'Serbia, stop' campaign, demanding responsibility for the death of 15 people after a canopy collapsed in Novi Sad. A man drove his car into the crowd . Four members of the orchestra were injured in the incident, 3 of them severely with fractures. The driver was later arrested.

On 5 December 2024, students occupied Faculties of Mechanical and Civil Engineering, as well as the Faculty of Geography in Belgrade, thus joining their peers in a widespread movement, deciding to occupy their faculty buildings, demanding the publication of documents related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against the individuals who attacked students during the protests. This action was part of a nationwide wave of protests, during which students occupied their faculties, all sharing the same demands, announcing that the occupation would continue until these demands were met.

On 5 December 2024, students, along with several professors, blocked traffic in front of the Rectorate building in Belgrade - Stari Grad at 11:52, at the exact moment when the concrete canopy collapsed at the train station in Novi Sad, to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives in the tragedy. The participants gathered at Student's Square to read the names of the deceased. The protesters then read their names at the Student's Square. The students held banners attributing the tragedy to corruption during the renovation of the Novi Sad railway building and called for accountability from the authorities. Additionally, they continued the occupation of various faculties, which had originally begun on November 26 at the Faculty of Dramatic Arts and then spread across the country.

On 5 December 2024, students from the Faculty of Philology and Arts (FILUM) gathered in front of the Knjazevsko-Srpski Theater in Kragujevac, to show support for their peers who are occupying faculties in Belgrade, Novi Sad, and Nis, honor the victims of the tragedy in Novi Sad and to protest against the arrests of students and professors during and after the protests sparked by this tragedy in the past month.

notes: On 4 December 2024, citizens and activists of the initiative 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje'), including a professor from the Faculty of Biology and MPs from SSP and DS, blocked for the fourth time the intersection of streets leading towards the contested luxury residential neighborhood Belgrade Waterfront in Belgrade - Savski Venac to protest against the removal of the Old Sava Bridge. A group of around 20 masked counter-protesters attacked the protesters, and in response one of them was sprayed with pepper spray. A journalist from the pro-government media outlet Informer was insulted by the crowd, and a masked rioter threatened and pushed the camera of a journalist from N1 television. The police intervened and arrested five masked individuals involved in the confrontation. At one point, a driver attempted to forcefully pass through the blockade but fortunately did not injure anyone.

This action was part of a nationwide wave of protests, during which students occupied their faculties, all sharing the same demands, announcing that the occupation would continue until these demands were met.

They then proceeded to occupy the academic institution, joining their peers from Belgrade and Novi Sad. This action was part of a nationwide wave of protests, during which students occupied their faculties, all sharing the same demands, announcing that the occupation would continue until these demands were met.

Students in Novi Sad also demand the resignation of the city's mayor and of the Serbian Prime Minister. This action was part of a nationwide wave of protests, during which students occupied their faculties, all sharing the same demands, announcing that the occupation would continue until these demands were met.
