source: BETA; Danas; FoNet; N1TV Online - Serbia
notes: On 3 December 2024, around 200 citizens and opposition members from PSG, NPS, Ecological Uprising, DS, PZP: Movement for Reversal and SSP, including several MPs, gathered in front of the Novi Sad Assembly to demand the resignation of Novi Sad's mayor. As the Assembly members deliberated on this issue, police officers and Assembly security personnel pushed back the protesters who attempted to enter the building, resulting in injuries to one protester. Some protesters claim that they were beaten by the police and security members. During the event, a group of protesters seized and damaged the phone of a journalist from the pro-government media outlet 'Informer' while she was reporting. Several protesters were arrested, including an activist from the organization 'Stav'. Tensions escalated during the Assembly session, where its President accused a member of the opposition from the citizens' movement 'Bravo' of physically attacking Novi Sad's mayor. Ultimately, the Assembly decided to retain the mayor in office. Two days later, a Vojvodina official from PSG was arrested accused of assaulting a police officer during the protest in front of the City's Assembly building in Novi Sad.

On 3 December 2024, students from the Faculties of Architecture and Political Science in Belgrade joined their peers in a widespread movement, deciding to occupy their faculty buildings, demanding the publication of documentation related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested at the protests, the filing of criminal charges against the attackers of the students during the protests, as well as 20% increase in funding for state universities. This protest was part of a larger movement, with students across the country occupying their faculties and voicing the same demands. Students stated that they would camp overnight in their faculties until their demands were addressed. Students also gathered in front of the Faculty of Political Sciences in Belgrade - Vozdovac at 11:52, the exact time when the canopy collapsed, and paused their activities for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims.

On 2 December 2024, students occupied the Rectorate building, as well as the Faculties of Philosophy, Philology, Chemistry and Mathematics in Belgrade, demanding the publication of documentation related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested at the protests, the filing of criminal charges against the attackers of the students during the protests, as well as 20% increase in funding for state universities. A group of 150 students of Dramatic Arts gathered in front of the Students' park to show support for their colleagues who joined the blockade which they initially started a week before (coded separately). This protest was part of a larger movement, with students across the country occupying their faculties and voicing the same demands. Students stated that they would camp overnight in their faculties until their demands were addressed. Many professors expressed support for the students' actions.

On 2 December 2024, high school students, along with members of the student group 'STAV,' gathered in front of 'Jovan Jovanovic Zmaj' high school to protest the way tabloid media reported on them and their professors, because of their participation in the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, which involved pausing activities for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy and demand accountability for this tragic event. Later that day, the students and members of 'STAV' occupied the Faculty of Philosophy in Novi Sad. They demanded the publication of documentation related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station in Novi Sad, the release and dismissal of charges against those arrested during the protests, the filing of criminal charges against those who attacked students during the protests, and a 20% increase in funding for state universities. This protest was part of a larger movement, with students across the country occupying their faculties and voicing the same demands. Students stated that they would camp overnight in their faculties until their demands were addressed. Many professors expressed support for the students' actions.

assoc_actor_1: PSG: Movement of Free Citizens; Students (Serbia)
notes: On 1 December 2024, several thousand citizens, organized by the groups 'Stav' and 'Svice,' along with students and high school students, marched from the Square of Freedom to the Railway Station in Novi Sad. This protest marked one month since the tragic collapse of the concrete canopy at the train station, which resulted in the deaths of 15 people. The protesters demanded accountability for the incident, calling for the resignation of the mayor of Novi Sad and the Serbian Prime Minister, as well as the publication of documentation related to the reconstruction of the Railway Station. To symbolize the blood on the authorities' hands, protesters painted the square red. The Public Utility Company 'Gradska Cistoca' responsible for cleaning the city, claimed that the protesters attacked city cleaners while they were removing the paint. However, a video circulated on social media showing a man, supposedly a city cleaner, not in uniform physically attacking a youth representative of the PSG by knocking him down, dragging him on the ground, and hitting him.

On 1 December 2024, citizens, organized by the initiative 'Let's Defend Yugo' ('Odbranimo Jugu'), staged a protest in front of the 'Hotel Jugoslavija' in Belgrade - Novi Beograd against the hotel's demolition and called on the authorities to conduct a study to determine whether the demolition is releasing asbestos and other toxic materials into the air. The protesters demanded that the demolition work cease until this study is completed and insisted on criminal charges against those responsible for the illegal management of the demolition debris.

On 1 December 2024, citizens gathered in front of the Presidency of Serbia in Belgrade - Stari Grad to mark the one-month anniversary of the canopy collapse at the Novi Sad train station, which resulted in the deaths of 15 people. The gathering was organized by a former basketball player who has set up a camp at the site since the day before. He stated that he will remain there until both the Serbian Prime Minister and the mayor of Novi Sad resign.

On 30 November 2024, a member of the 'Bravo' movement and a member of the ruling SNS political party were involved in a physical altercation. The incident occurred when the 'Bravo' member attempted to put up posters and stickers at the SNS premises in Futog. The SNS member claims that the 'Bravo' member twisted her arm, resulting in a visit to the Emergency Center. However, officials from 'Bravo' deny these allegations, accusing the SNS member of falsifying her medical records, noting that she is also employed as a head nurse at the Clinical Center Vojvodina (KCV).

On 29 November 2024, several tens of citizens, along with members of the opposition, gathered in Cacak to participate in a 15-minute pause as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign. This campaign took place in various cities across Serbia and called on everyone to halt their activities for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy at the railway station in Novi Sad collapsed at 11:52. The gatherings were held at this specific time to commemorate the tragedy. The campaign aimed to show support for the victims' families and demand accountability from the authorities responsible for this tragic event.

On 29 November 2024, citizens, along with opposition members, gathered in Kragujevac to pause all their activities for 15 minutes as part of the 'Serbia, stop' campaign. This campaign again took place in various cities across Serbia and called for everyone to pause their activities for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy at the railway station in Novi Sad collapsed at 11:52. This is why the gatherings were taking place at this exact moment when the tragedy happened. The campaign aimed to show support for the families of victims, but also demand accountability from the authorities and those responsible for the tragic event.

On 29 November 2024, citizens gathered in Loznica to pause all their activities for 15 minutes as part of the 'Serbia, stop' campaign. During their protest action, a man attacked with a baton one female protester, while one car driver attempted to break through, resulting in some protesters being thrown onto his car's hood. This initiative aimed to demand accountability from the authorities while honoring the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy, which occurred when a concrete canopy collapsed at the city's railway station.

On 29 November 2024, citizens gathered in Nis to pause all their activities for 15 minutes as part of the 'Serbia, stop' campaign. A group of citizens shouted and insulted the protesters for blocking the road. The 'Serbia, stop' initiative aimed to demand accountability from the authorities while honoring the 15 victims of the Novi Sad tragedy, which occurred when a concrete canopy collapsed at the city's railway station.

On 29 November 2024, education workers from Southern Serbia, along with their union representatives, held a protest in Nis to demand better working conditions and higher salaries. As of November, educators across Serbia are participating in strikes, resulting in shortened school classes.

notes: On 28 November 2024, around 20 opposition members, including national and provincial MPs, local councilors, and representatives from the SSP, DS, NPS, PSG, and Green-Left Front, blocked again the entrance to the Court and Prosecution Office in Novi Sad during working hours, demanding that their employees fulfill their duties and find those responsible for the tragedy in which 15 people lost their lives, following the collapse of a concrete canopy at the train station in Novi Sad. The protesters also called for the release of all detained politicians and activists who had been imprisoned during and after the protests related to this event. In response, the police used shields to push and disperse the protesters. Gendarmerie members were also present and set up a metal protective fence in front of the main entrance to prevent access to the stairs where several violent incidents and injuries had occurred during previous protests. In response, opposition members locked those fences with padlocks, blocking access for the Court and Prosecution Office employees.

notes: On 27 November 2024, activists from the initiative 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje') placed construction debris in front of the City's Assembly in Belgrade - Stari Grad to oppose the project of the Old Sava bridge removal. Following this, several hundred activists, citizens and opposition MPs and politicians from the SSP, PSG, Ecological Uprising, and SRCE parties, blocked in protest the intersection of Vudro Vilson and Nikolaja Kravcova streets leading towards the contested luxury residential neighborhood Belgrade Waterfront in Belgrade - Savski Venac, which is perceived as the main reason for the bridge's removal. A group of several tens of counter-protesters wearing black hoodies pushed against the protesters, attempting to break through their blockade, while some pulled out knives. While covering the event, demonstrators attempted to seize the microphone from an N1TV journalist, punching her in the shoulder. The cameraman from the same station was also assaulted. The co-chairman of the Committee for the Judiciary and trustee of the Municipal Committee Savski venac from SRCE political party was also injured. Opposition politicians claimed to have identified members of the ruling SNS party among the rioters, including the President of the Zemun Municipality and a local councilor from Novi Beograd Municipality.

On 27 November 2024, citizens, along with the co-president of the political party Together, protested in front of the police station in Sabac demanding accountability for a violent attack of hooligans on environmental protesters that occurred three years earlier in their city.

notes: On 27 November 2024, a physical fight broke out in the City Assembly in Kraljevo between opposition and ruling SNS councillors. There were no reports on injuries and councillors were separated by the security team.

On 26 November 2024, residents of Block 4 protested in front of the construction site located at Pariske Komune 65-69 street in Belgrade - Novi Beograd, claiming that it caused damages to their adjacent building and demanding that an inspection team arrive to assess the situation.

On 26 November 2024, students gathered and blocked the entrance to their Faculty of Dramatic Arts (FDU) in Belgrade - Novi Beograd in order to protest against the violence that occurred against art students and professors in front of this institution during the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign which happened on November 22. The campaign involved pausing activities and blocking traffic for 15 minutes to honor 15 victims of the collapse of the concrete canopy at Novi Sad's train station and to demand accountability from the authorities for this tragic event.

assoc_actor_1: Ecological Uprising; Government of Serbia (2017-); Green-Left Front; NPS: People's Movement of Serbia; PSG: Movement of Free Citizens; SRCE: Serbia Centre; SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice
assoc_actor_2: Government of Serbia (2017-); SNS: Serbian Progressive Party
notes: On 25 November 2024, members of the ruling SNS political party and opposition parties, including PSG, SSP, NPS, SRCE, the Green-Left Front, and Ecological Uprising, engaged in a physical fight during a session of the National Assembly of Serbia in Belgrade - Stari Grad. During the session, opposition members blew whistles, held banners and shouted 'murderers,' calling for a vote of confidence in light of a tragic incident in which 15 people lost their lives when a recently renovated concrete canopy at the train station in Novi Sad collapsed. During the confrontation, the President of the National Assembly turned off the microphones and later claimed that opposition politicians had damaged several microphones and one screen during the clash. No reports of injuries.

On 25 November 2024, women's rights activists participated in a performative protest in Nis. They stood still and held banners displaying the names of femicide victims to commemorate the International Day for the Elimination of Violence Against Women. This event aimed to raise awareness about the alarming statistic that, since the beginning of this year, 17 women have been killed in Serbia.

assoc_actor_2: Police Forces of Serbia (2017-) Security Intelligence Agency
notes: On 24 November 2024, around 1300 citizens, organized by the groups 'SviCe' and 'Stav', protested in front of the railway station in Novi Sad by blocking the traffic and leaving red handprint along the road, symbolizing the 'bloody' hands of the authorities. The protest was a demand for accountability following the death of 15 people due to the collapse of the concrete canopy at the city's train station for which they blame a faulty renovation process. After blocking the road, the protesters began a march to the police station where they demanded the release of a 'SviCe' activist who was arrested prior to the protest by three man who identified themselves as members of BIA (Security Intelligence Agency). During the march, one passer-by threw eggs at the protesters, and knocked the phone out of the hand of a Danas journalist while he was reporting from the event.

assoc_actor_1: SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice
notes: On 24 November 2024, citizens, activists and opposition members from SSP blocked the start of removal machinery work at the Old Sava bridge in Belgrade - Novi Beograd. The police intervened, pushing away the protesters, including two female MPs from the SSP. Activists had been camping at the site since November 1 to prevent the removal of the bridge.

assoc_actor_1: DS: Democratic Party; NPS: People's Movement of Serbia; SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice
assoc_actor_2: Government of Serbia (2017-); SNS: Serbian Progressive Party
notes: On 23 November 2024, approximately 100 citizens and activists from the initiative 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje'), along with representatives from the DS and NPS, protested against the removal of the Old Sava bridge by blocking the road leading towards the contested luxury residential neighborhood Belgrade Waterfront in Belgrade - Savski Venac, which is perceived as the main reason for the bridge's removal. Frustrated drivers, upset by the road blockage, yelled at and pushed the protesters. Organizers of the protest allege that some of these individuals infiltrated the demonstration intentionally, while the SSP officials claimed that among them there were the President of the Municipalities Cukarica and Rakovica from the ruling SNS party.

On 22 November 2024, citizen gathered in Kovacica to pause all their activities for 15 minutes as part of the 'Serbia, stop' campaign. This campaign, organized by members of the opposition took place in various cities across Serbia and called for everyone to pause their activities for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy at the railway station in Novi Sad collapsed at 11:52. This is why the gatherings were taking place at this exact moment when the tragedy happened. The campaign aimed to show support for the families of victims, but also demand accountability from the authorities and those responsible for the tragic event.

On 22 November 2024, around 100 citizens organized by opposition members including representatives from SRCE, gathered in Krusevac outside the City Assembly where they paused all their activities for 15 minutes as part of the 'Serbia, stop' campaign. This campaign which took place in various cities across Serbia called for everyone to pause their activities for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy at the railway station in Novi Sad collapsed at 11:52. The campaign aimed to show support for the families of victims, but also demand accountability from the authorities and those responsible for the tragic event. assoc_actor_1: Government of Serbia (2017-); Journalists (Serbia); SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice; Students (Serbia); Teachers (Serbia); SRCE: Serbia Centre
assoc_actor_2: Government of Serbia (2017-); SNS: Serbian Progressive Party
source: Danas; FoNet; Juzne Vesti; N1TV Online - Serbia
notes: On 22 November 2024, around 2500 citizens gathered at various locations in Belgrade - including Branko's bridge (along with representatives from the SSP and SRCE), in front of the Faculty of Dramatic Arts (FDU) in Novi Beograd, in front of the Faculty of Philology, in front of the Faculty of Law, in front of the Radio and Television of Serbia (RTS) on Takovska Street (several tens people along with the representatives of the initiative 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje')), at the intersection near the London neighborhood in Stari Grad, and at Student's Square (with the most massive gathering of around 1100 people). They paused all their activities for 15 minutes as part of the 'Serbia, Stop' campaign, which involved blocking traffic throughout the city. At two locations, the demonstration turned violent. In front of the Faculty of Dramatic Arts, where students and professors gathered in front of their faculty, several car drivers refused to stop and engaged in a fight with the demonstrators, during which a journalist from Nova.rs was also attacked while reporting on the event. The SSP political party later claimed that among those who attacked the students were two members of the local administration from the ruling SNS party. Another confrontation took place in front of the national television building, where a group of rioters clashed with demonstrators. An individual exited his car and violently tried to take umbrellas from the demonstrators, throwing away papers they were holding that bore the names of the victims from Novi Sad. In response, one demonstrator used pepper spray, leading to further violence as a group of rioters engaged in a fight with the demonstrators. The 'Serbia, Stop' campaign was organized by opposition members and took place in various cities across Serbia, calling for everyone to pause their activities for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy at the railway station in Novi Sad collapsed at 11:52. The gatherings coincided with the exact moment of the tragedy. The campaign aimed to show support for the families of victims, but also demand accountability from the authorities and those responsible for the tragic event.

This is why the gatherings were taking place at this exact moment when the tragedy happened. The campaign aimed to show support for the families of victims, but also demand accountability from the authorities and those responsible for the tragic event.

This campaign, organized by members of the opposition took place in various cities across Serbia and called for everyone to pause their activities for 15 minutes to honor the 15 victims who lost their lives when the concrete canopy at the railway station in Novi Sad collapsed at 11:52. The campaign aimed to show support for the families of victims, but also demand accountability from the authorities and those responsible for the tragic event.

assoc_actor_1: Ecological Uprising; Government of Serbia (2017-); PSG: Movement of Free Citizens; SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice
notes: On 21 November 2024, citizens, along with members of the opposition, SSP and MPs from the Ecological Uprising and PSG, staged a protest at the Old Sava Bridge in Belgrade - Novi Beograd, by blocking the makeshift access route for trucks and construction machines attempting to reach the bridge. The protesters also blocked Zemunski put by using trash cans. Besides opposing the removal of the bridge, protesters also call for a ban on the crossing of trucks weighing more than 3.5 tons, as well as for the reconstruction of the bridge, and for the bridge to be declared as a protected cultural asset.

assoc_actor_1: DS: Democratic Party; Government of Serbia (2017-); Green-Left Front; NPS: People's Movement of Serbia; PSG: Movement of Free Citizens; SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice; Together; SRCE: Serbia Centre
notes: On 21 November 2024, opposition members, including national and provincial MPs and representatives from the SSP, PSG, DS, Together, SRCE, NPS, Movement for Reversal, and Green-Left Front, along with activists and citizens, blocked the entrance to the Court and Prosecution Office in Novi Sad for the third consecutive day. They demanded that their employees fulfill their duties and find those responsible for the tragedy in which 15 people lost their lives, one of whom died in the hospital, following the collapse of a concrete canopy at the train station in Novi Sad. The protesters also called for the release of politicians and activists who had been imprisoned during and after the protests over the past two and a half weeks in Novi Sad. Members of the gendarmerie were again also present. Protesters hustled with the police, during which some of the protesters fell from the stairs, while a fence was broken, and the doors to the court, as well as part of the stairway was damaged. Members of the gendarmerie were again also present. One of the police officers has hit with a fist one of the protesters, while a 74 years old man sprayed tear gas in one of the policeman's eyes, for which he was arrested. The citizens' movement Bravo later stated that he was severely beaten by the police at the station, which led to serious injuries, necessitating a testicle amputation.

assoc_actor_1: DS: Democratic Party; Government of Serbia (2017-); Start-Change; Students (Serbia)
notes: On 20 November 2024, police officers arrived on both sides of the Old Sava Bridge in Belgrade, where protesters and activists from the initiative 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje') had been camping since November 1 to prevent the removal of the bridge. The police forcibly removed the leader of the Start-Change movement, along with a local councilor from the same group, and took them to a police car for arrest. During the arrest, the Start-Change leader began to feel unwell, so he sought medical assistance. After the incident, protesters attempted to break through the police cordon which was allowing workers to begin the removal of tram tracks and asphalt. In response, activists blocked Vudro Vilson Street, thus preventing any traffic from reaching the controversial luxury residential block Belgrade waterfront, which was seen as the primary reason for the bridge's removal. The protest then briefly continued at Branko's bridge in Belgrade - Stari Grad, where between 300 and 400 activists and citizens, along with the leader of the DS blocked traffic. However, after receiving the information that the police had surrounded the protesters' camp at Old Sava bridge, about 200 participants decided to go back to that location. Police prevented between 100 and 200 protesters from crossing the bridge to reach Belgrade - Novi Beograd, where the leader of the 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje') encouraged everyone to gather and prevent the work of removal machinery. The police detained four students and activists, who were later released. The protest leader announced plans to set up a new camp on the other side of the bridge in Belgrade-Novi Beograd.

assoc_actor_1: DS: Democratic Party; Government of Serbia (2017-); Green-Left Front; NPS: People's Movement of Serbia; PSG: Movement of Free Citizens; Students (Serbia)
notes: On 20 November 2024, students and activists from the group 'Borba', along with a local councilor from PSG, and other members from the same political party, representatives from the NPS, the president of the DS, and MPs from the Green-Left Front, blocked the entrance to the Rectorate building in Belgrade - Stari Grad. They were protesting for not being allowed to attend the ceremony celebrating the International Students' Day, as well as against any festivity given that 15 people recently lost their lives following the collapse of a concrete canopy at the train station in Novi Sad. On his way to the protest, an activist from 'Borba' was arrested. During the arrest, police officers twisted his arm. He was later released and re-joined the protest. Students entered the hall where the celebration was taking place, following a brief hustling with security personnel and stopped the ceremony. Students then joined other protesters at the Old Sava Bridge (coded separately).

assoc_actor_1: DS: Democratic Party; Ecological Uprising; Government of Serbia (2017-); Green-Left Front; Journalists (Serbia); NPS: People's Movement of Serbia; PSG: Movement of Free Citizens; SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice
notes: On 20 November 2024, opposition members, including national and provincial MPs and representatives from the SSP, DS, PSG, NPS, Ecological Uprising, and Green-Left Front, along with activists and citizens, blocked the entrance to the Court and Prosecution Office in Novi Sad for the second consecutive day. They demanded that their employees fulfill their duties and find those responsible for the tragedy in which 15 people lost their lives, one of whom died in the hospital, following the collapse of a concrete canopy at the train station in Novi Sad. The protesters also called for the release of politicians and activists who had been imprisoned during and after the protests over the past two and a half weeks in Novi Sad. In response, the police and gendarmerie used shields to push and kick the protesters away from the entrance. The President of PSG in Novi Sad suffered injuries during the clash, having been hit in the shins and ribs. An MP from the Ecological Uprising was also injured when the police knocked her down on the stairs outside the entrance. A representative from the Green-Left Front fainted after breaking through the police cordon and entering the building. At some point, one of the policemen's gun accidentally fell from its holster. A journalist from 021.rs was also pushed away by the court's security guards while covering the event. On the same day, the Minister of Internal and Foreign Trade resigned from his position.

assoc_actor_1: DS: Democratic Party; Government of Serbia (2017-); Green-Left Front; NPS: People's Movement of Serbia; PSG: Movement of Free Citizens; SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice
notes: On 19 November 2024, opposition members, including national and provincial MPs, local councilors, and representatives from the SSP, DS, NPS, PSG, and Green-Left Front, blocked the entrance to the Court and Prosecution Office in Novi Sad during working hours, demanding that their employees fulfill their duties and find those responsible for the tragedy in which 15 people lost their lives, following the collapse of a concrete canopy at the train station in Novi Sad. The protesters also called for the release of politicians and activists who had been imprisoned during and after the protests over the past two and a half weeks in Novi Sad. In response, the police used shields to push and kick the protesters away from the entrance, attempting to allow employees to enter the building. The Association of Judges and Prosecutors of Serbia later said that in the crowd, one person violently pushed a Judge of the High Court in Novi Sad while she attempted to enter the building. The following day, the police announced they would file a criminal complaint against the PSG Youth President in Novi Sad for assaulting an officer during the protest.

On 19 November 2024, citizens organized by the 'Valjevo Resistance Movement' ('Valjevski pokret otpora') staged a protest in Valjevo in front of the 'Euro Litijum Balkan' demanding that the company cease its operations in the city. The Canadian company had recently announced that it would not study lithium, but borate minerals, and their geothermal potential. Following the protest organized last week in Valjevo for the same cause, several people were invited for an 'informative interview with the police'.

On 18 November 2024, employees of bankrupt social enterprises protested again in front of the City Hall in Nis, expressing their dissatisfaction with how the recently adopted City Assembly program is being implemented. They are unhappy about having their salaries paid in four instalments and are unwilling to forfeit interest on unpaid wages. Furthermore, the city's list does not include the names of all affected employees. Additionally, the queues to sign the agreement with the city are excessively long, causing many employees to abandon their wait or be denied the opportunity to take the agreement to their lawyers for consultation.

assoc_actor_1: Government of Serbia (2017-); NPS: People's Movement of Serbia
notes: On 17 November 2024, citizens, including a national MP from the NPS political party, organized by the initiatives 'Svice' and 'Stav', blocked in protest the intersection of two boulevards in front of the railway station in Novi Sad. They demanded accountability for the deaths of 15 people (one more person died in the meantime in the hospital), resulting from the collapse of a concrete canopy at the train station in their city. Protesters held a large banner depicting a white pigeon (symbol of Novi Sad) bleeding and crying, and stained the street with red handprints, symbolizing the 'blood on the hands' of the authorities. Tensions escalated when two men, holding flags of the EU and 'Maidan Serbia,' clashed with the demonstrators after refusing to leave the protest area. One of these men claimed to be the President of the Association 'Responsibility' ('Odgovornost') and began pushing the security guards present at the protest. During the confrontation, a metal spear from one of the flags was broken.

assoc_actor_1: SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice
notes: On 15 November 2024, MPs and local councilors from the SSP gathered in front of the Supreme Public Prosecutor's Office in Belgrade - Savski Venac, holding a black canvas to support the campaign '14 minutes for 14 victims' which called for everyone to pause their activities and stand in the street at the exact moment when the concrete canopy at the railway station collapsed, killing 14 people in Novi Sad 14 days prior.

On 15 November 2024, large group of citizens, organized by the initiative 'Let's Defend Yugo' ('Odbranimo Jugu'), protested in Belgrade - Zemun against the demolition of the 'Hotel Jugoslavija' (a symbol of Tito's Yugoslavia) which started that day for the sake of building a luxury residential and business complex. Some of the protesters tore the advertising tarpaulins placed on the construction site fence.

assoc_actor_1: Farmers (Serbia); Health Workers (Serbia); Journalists (Serbia); Labor Group (Serbia); Students (Serbia); Teachers (Serbia)
notes: On 15 November 2024, people gathered at various locations in Novi Sad, as part of the campaign '14 minutes for 14 victims' which called for everyone to pause their activities and stand in the street at the exact moment when the concrete canopy at the railway station collapsed, killing 14 people in Novi Sad 14 days prior. The campaign aimed to show support for the families of victims, but also demand accountability from the authorities and those responsible for the tragic event. The largest crowd gathered in front of the railway station where the accident took place, while several hundred citizens blocked the street at the roundabout of Bulevar oslobodenja and Bulevar Jase Tomica. They held a black ribbon and released 14 balloons, each inscribed with the message 'Corruption is killing.' Citizens also blocked Bulevar Mihajla Pupina. Additionally, students and professors from the Faculty of Science and Mathematics, the Faculty of Medicine, and several highschools, including Karlovac and Laza Kostic highschools, gathered in front of their academic institutions. Actors and employees of the Youth Theater, as well as employees and journalists from Vojvodina Radio and Television, the Oil Industries of Serbia and the Clinical Center of Vojvodina participated outside their workplaces. At the request of a lawyer, witness hearings in the case against a former Vojvodina official who had been arrested during a protest a week earlier were interrupted for 14 minutes. Farmers in the suburban areas of Novi Sad also blocked roads in Kisac and Cenej. The campaign was initiated by members of opposition political parties in Novi Sad.

On 14 November 2024, three men physically assaulted the local councilor, who also serves as the vice president of the Novi Sad PSG board, at the cultural center SKC Fabrika in Novi Sad. The attackers, members of the security staff at the cultural center, grabbed him by the neck, pulled him to the ground, and started strangling him. During the incident, the girlfriend of the PSG official was also slightly injured. The PSG official has accused the ruling SNS political party of being behind the attack.

On 14 November 2024, employees of 'Pro Tent' stopped working for several hours and gathered in front of the Directorate of Thermal Power Plants and Mines in Kostolac demanding equal pay with employees of EPS (Electric Power Industry of Serbia) for performing the same type of work. Additionally, they requested the same early retirement benefits that EPS employees receive.

On 13 November 2024, professors and students from the Academy of Art in Novi Sad gathered in front of the prosecution office and court in Novi Sad to demand the release of a student who had been arrested during the protests in their city on November 5, 2024.

On 12 November 2024, around 200 citizens (according to the Archive of public gatherings), organized by the 'Valjevo Resistance Movement' ('Valjevski pokret otpora'), staged a protest in Valjevo against lithium and borate mining, during which protesters threw eggs to the Info center of the Canadian company 'Euro Litijum Balkan'. In response, 'Euro Litijum Balkan' announced it would file a criminal complaint against the protest organizers.

On 12 November 2024, citizens, along with representatives of the Associations of Independent Pharmacists 'Udruzenje samostalnih apotekara', staged a protest in Kraljevo in front of the city administration office demanding a referendum regarding the potential closure of Pharmacy Kraljevo, supported by 11.000 signatures which is legally sufficient to call for a referendum.

assoc_actor_1: DS: Democratic Party; Ecological Uprising; Green-Left Front; SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice
notes: On 11 November 2024, between 9,000 and 10,000 citizens (according to the Archive of public gatherings) along with representatives from various opposition political parties-including the Ecological Uprising, SRCE: Srbija centar, Green-Left Front, DS, SSP, and the former mayor of Novi Sad - marched in protest from the Serbian government's building to the Presidency building in Belgrade - Stari Grad, demanding the resignation of the Prime Minister and the mayor of Novi Sad, holding them accountable for the deaths of 14 people Novi Sad, which occurred after the collapse of a concrete canopy at the train station. The protesters also called for a criminal prosecution of everyone responsible for this tragic event, the publication of all secret contracts related to the recent reconstruction of the train station in Novi Sad, and a control of all infrastructure projects that have been carried out in the last 10 years.

On 10 November 2024, residents of Opovo blocked Zrenjaninski put in Belgrade - Palilula to protest against the removal of the only suburban public transport line that was connecting them with the city's center.

Property destruction: On 10 November 2024, an unidentified individual or individuals shattered a window displaying a picture of the Serbian President at the premises of the ruling SNS political party in Kragujevac. Party officials have accused members of the opposition of being responsible for the attack, while opposition politicians have denied these claims.

Property destruction: On 9 November 2024, an unknown individual or individuals broke the window of the ruling SNS political party's premises in Kragujevac. Party officials accused members of the opposition of the attack, while opposition politicians denied these claims.

assoc_actor_1: LSV: League of Social Democrats of Vojvodina; Ecological Uprising; Government of Serbia (2017-)
notes: On 8 November 2024, around 1.500 citizens, organized by the group SviCe, staged another protest by blocking the Varadin Bridge in Novi Sad demanding accountability for the deaths of 14 people in their city, which occurred after the collapse of a concrete canopy at the train station. Protesters stained the bridge with red handprints, symbolizing the 'blood on the hands' of the authorities. A group including members of the LSV, the 'Bravo' coalition, and the Ecological Uprising also gathered in front of the Stari Grad Police Station in Novi Sad, demanding the release of activists who had been arrested prior to the protest. The activists were released later that day, but the police detained a city councilor. Meanwhile, a former vice president of the Vojvodina government, who had been initially released, turned himself in to the police after being remanded in custody for 30 days.

On 8 November 2024, members of the ZLF political party protested in front of the Prokop railway station in Belgrade - Savski Venac, demanding the closure of the station, claiming it lacked the necessary permissions and had not provided evidence of passing a technical inspection. This protest was triggered by a recent incident in which a concrete canopy collapsed at a railway station in Novi Sad, resulting in the deaths of at least 14 people.

On 8 November 2024, employees of bankrupt social enterprises protested again in front of the City Hall in Nis, due to a lack of trust and dissatisfaction with the recently adopted City's Assembly program which plans out to pay unpaid salaries to these employees in four instalments, as the list does not contain the names of all affected employees, as well as the program does not cover interest on the unpaid wages, nor does it cover court and attorney costs.

On 7 November 2024, a member of the Kovin municipal assembly from the ruling SNS political party physically assaulted a Kovinske Info journalist during the assembly session. He punched the journalist several times with his elbow and pushed him, after he asked a question to the Assembly President. He then attempted to take away his mobile phone with which he was recording the session, and twisted his arm.

On 7 November 2024, citizens staged a protest in front of the court in Novi Sad against the detention of the former vice president of the Vojvodina Government and several activists who were arrested during protests two days prior in Novi Sad. The former Vojvodina's official was released on the same day.

assoc_actor_1: Protesters (Serbia); Green-Left Front; SSP: Party of Freedom and Justice; NPS: People's Movement of Serbia; Students (Serbia); Journalists (Serbia); Government of Serbia (2017-)
source: FoNet; N1TV Online - Serbia; Safe Journalists
notes: On 5 November 2024, around 22.000 (according to the Archive of public gatherings) citizens, students and activists from the groups 'SviCe' and 'Stav', along with many politicians, including representatives from the ZLF, SSP, NPS and the coalition 'Bravo', gathered in front of the railway station in Novi Sad where a few days before 14 people lost their lives following the collapse of a concrete canopy. The demonstrators demanded the resignation of the Minister of Construction and Infrastructure, the Prime Minister, mayor of Novi Sad and the Serbian government, holding them accountable for the tragic event, due to corruption and oversight during the recent renovation of the railway building. Some of the demonstrators were holding red banners, symbolizing the blood on the authorities' hands. Others threw red paint and removed Serbian flags hanging at the entrance of the nearby ruling SNS political party premises. Some masked individuals later broke their windows using bats and threw bricks. After initial gathering in front of the railway station, demonstrators marched to the City Hall, where some demonstrators hurled rocks and paint at City Hall, breaking windows, while the councilor at the Assembly of Novi Sad released dirty water from the cistern, claiming it was faeces. Masked men attempted to enter the City Hall, after which the police threw tear gas at the demonstrators. The clash escalated, with rioters throwing objects, baseball bats, and flares at the police, while some climbed through windows and removed or damaged the video surveillance cameras at City Hall. In response, the police threw tear gas and pepper spray at the crowd. During this clash, one of the flares ignited a small fire on the ground floor. During these events, a team of reporters from N1TV Station was attacked in front of City Hall, and their camera was damaged. Videographer working for Euronews was also physically assaulted when someone violently threw him on the ground while he was recording the demonstration. The journalistic crew of the Portal 021.rs from Novi Sad was hit with plastic bottles and sprayed with paint while reporting. Members of the opposition parties claimed that the rioters were groups of sports fans aligned with the authorities who had infiltrated demonstration intentionally. At least 14 people and activists were arrested during the demonstration and in the days that followed, including a city's councilor from the 'Bravo' coalition, a former vice-president of the Vojvodina government, and a local councilor who released dirty water from the cistern.

Property destruction: Around 4 November 2024 (as reported), an unidentified individual or individuals broke the window and sprayed graffiti on the wall with the message 'Murderers' of the ruling SNS political party's premises in the Podbar neighborhood of Novi Sad.

assoc_actor_2: Protesters (Serbia); Government of Serbia (2017-); Labor Group (Serbia); SNS: Serbian Progressive Party
notes: On 4 November 2024, citizens organized by the Association 'NOT to Take a Deep Breath' (Da (NE) Disemo Duboko) blocked in protest garbage disposal operations at the Duboko wild landfill in Uzice. For the past three months, they have been camping near the landfill to prevent the dumping of garbage and demanding its closure due to concerns about pollution affecting the water, land, and air in the surrounding area. Employees of public enterprises, the mayor, the deputy mayor, and local authorities held a counter-protest. Tension escalated between the two groups, resulting in some pushing and shoving. During the confrontation, counter-protesters attempted to tear down a poster held by one of the protesters. The police detained two protesters. Several days later, local authorities announced their decision to shut down the Duboko landfill.

On 3 November 2024, several thousands of citizens, organized by the group SviCe, gathered at Savski Venac and marched in protest to the Serbian Government's building in Belgrade - Savski Venac, voicing their dissatisfaction with the corruption which they believe led to the recent deaths of 14 people in Novi Sad, following the collapse of a concrete canopy at the city's train station. The demonstrators demanded the resignation of the Minister of Construction, Transportation and Infrastructure and the Serbian government, holding them responsible for the tragic event, due to corruption and oversight during the recent renovation of the railway building. At some point, demonstrators continued their protest in front of the Ministry of Construction before returning to the Government building where they left red handprints on the pavement to symbolize the 'blood on the hands' of the authorities. These handprints were also left at the Court of Appeal building. A portion of the protesters then joined those opposing the demolition of the Old Sava Bridge who have set up a camp last week, preventing construction. One of the organizers was arrested right before the protests started, but was later during the day released. The Minister of Construction and Infrastructure resigned in the following days.

assoc_actor_1: Albanian Ethnic Group (Serbia); Government of Serbia (2017-)
notes: On 3 November 2024, several tens of Albanians, including the President of the National Council of Albanians, protested in front of the police station in Medveda against deactivation of residence addresses of Albanians in the Presevo valley, demanding greater respect of language rights of Albanian ethnic community in Serbia, recognition of diplomas obtained from Kosovo universities, and greater presence of Albanians in state institutions.

On 1 November 2024, farmers from Southern Banat, including representatives from the Association 'Slozni Pidikanci', protested in Bavaniste, dissatisfied because the Ministry of Agriculture had not honored the agreement it made in July regarding subsidies for agricultural workers.

On 1 November 2024, between 1000 and 1200 citizens (according to the Archive of public gatherings) organized by the initiative 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje') protested against the removal and displacement of the Old Sava Bridge, blocking the streets leading to Belgrade Waterfront, before heading back to the Old Sava bridge in Belgrade - Novi Beograd.

On 1 November 2024, teachers and educational workers, including representatives of the Education Union of Serbia, gathered in front of the National Assembly and marched in protest to the Government of Serbia building in Belgrade - Savski Venac, demanding higher salaries.

On 1 November 2024, farmers, including representatives from the Association 'Stig', gathered in Bratinac, from where they headed towards Pozarevac where they blocked the main road with tractors in protest. They were dissatisfied because the Ministry of Agriculture had not honored the agreement it made in July regarding subsidies for agricultural workers.

On 1 November 2024, teachers and educational workers, including representatives of the Education Union of Serbia protested in Zajecar demanding higher salaries and a change to the criminal code that would make assault on teaching staff a criminal offence.

On 1 November 2024, around 600 teachers and educational workers (according to the Union of Education Workers) gathered in Nis to show support for their colleagues who were protesting in Belgrade, demanding higher wages, dissatisfied with the government's proposal to increase their salaries by 11%. While some were able to reach Belgrade, those who couldn't due to local transport carriers refusing to provide services decided to gather in Nis instead.

On 31 October 2024, citizens, organized by the initiative 'The Bridge Stays' ('Most ostaje') protested against the displacement of the Old Sava Bridge, a day before its scheduled removal, by marching from the Main Bus Station to the Old Sava Bridge, and then returning to the Main Bus Station in Belgrade - Savski Venac. The organizers announced their intention to stay at the bridge for several days in order to prevent the removal machinery from starting its work.

On 30 October 2024, activists from 'Women for Change' ('Zene za promene') hel a protest in the Square of Liberty in Novi Sad, demanding from the authorities the establishment of a mechanism to combat femicide. The protest was sparked by a recent incident in which a young woman was killed by her partner in Aleksinac, marking the 16th case of femicide in the country since the beginning of the year.

On 26 October 2024, around 200 residents of Block 4 protested again by blocking the streets Pariske komune 65-69 and the Street Tosin bunar in Belgrade - Novi Beograd, opposing the construction that started in their neighbourhood. They fear that this construction would obstruct sunlight, air, and hinder emergency services in the event of an emergency at a nearby residential building.

On 26 October 2024, citizens organized by the initiative 'Let's Defend Yugo' ('Odbranimo Jugu') protested in Belgrade - Zemun against the planned demolition of the 'Hotel Jugoslavija' (a symbol of Tito's Yugoslavia) for the sake of building a luxury residential and business complex.

assoc_actor_1: SEOS: Association of Ecological Organizations of Serbia
notes: On 26 October 2024, around 170 citizens and activists (according to the Archive of public gathering), organized by SEOS, along with the representatives of 'Zajedno' political party, blocked the crossroad near Jevremovac in Sabac to protest against lithium mining and Rio Tinto company.
On 25 October 2024, citizens protested in front of the City Administration building in Vrbas because the heating has not yet been turned on.

assoc_actor_1: SEOS: Association of Ecological Organizations of Serbia
notes: On 24 October 2024, between 850 and 1000 citizens (according to different sources), organized by the SEOS, protested in Cacak against lithium mining and the plans of the Rio Tinto company to build a lithium mine in the Jadar Valley.

Property destruction: On 24 October 2024, unidentified armed individual or individuals vandalized several monuments and broke a window at the auxiliary facility in the Islamic cemetery located in the Brodarevo settlement of Prijepolje. Brodarevo is a multiethnic community, and there has been another recent incident involving the vandalism of an Orthodox cemetery.
On 23 October 2024, artists kicked out of the BIGZ and Jugosped buildings protested on the Cvetni trg in Belgrade - Vracar to draw the public's attention to the lack of space for artists to work.

On 23 October 2024, residents of Block 4 in Belgrade - Novi Beograd protested by blocking an excavator from accessing a construction site on Pariske Komune Street. They expressed concerns that the construction would obstruct sunlight, air, and hinder emergency services in the event of an emergency at a nearby residential building.

Property destruction: On 22 October 2024, an unidentified individual or individuals broke a window at the premises of the ruling SNS party on Narodni Front Street in Novi Sad. Party officials have accused members of the opposition of being behind the attack.

On 20 October 2024, citizens, led by the initiative 'Most ostaje' ('The bridge stays'), organized a protest in front of the Faculty of Philosophy in Belgrade - Stari grad to oppose the dismantling of the Old Sava bridge. The protesters believe that the bridge represents a symbol of Belgrade and highlights the issue of potential traffic congestion if the bridge is removed.

assoc_actor_1: SEOS: Association of Ecological Organizations of Serbia
notes: On 19 October 2024, citizens, organized by SEOS, blocked the road from Loznica to Valjevo in Gornje Nedeljice to protest against lithium mining and the plans of the Rio Tinto company to build a lithium mine in the Jadar Valley. The protest was initiated because the members of the Serbian Parliament did not adopt a proposed law by the opposition to ban lithium mining in the country.

assoc_actor_1: SEOS: Association of Ecological Organizations of Serbia
notes: On 19 October 2024, citizens, organized by the SEOS, blocked the road Ibarska magistrala in Preljina to protest against the lithium mining and the plans of the Rio Tinto company to build a lithium mine in the Jadar Valley. The protest was initiated because the members of the Serbian Parliament did not adopt a proposed law by the opposition to ban lithium mining in the country.

assoc_actor_1: SEOS: Association of Ecological Organizations of Serbia
notes: On 16 October 2024, around 2000 people (as per estimations of the Archive of Public Gathering), organized by the SEOS, along with representatives of oppositional political parties, protested in Loznica against lithium mining. The protest was initiated after the members of the Serbian Parliament did not adopt a law proposed by the opposition to ban lithium mining in the country.

Around 16 October 2024 (as reported), Novi Pazar Football Club fans protested in Novi Pazar against the Serbian Football Association's decision to play the upcoming match against Partizan without spectators, because of their offensive chanting and banners.

On 15 October 2024, activists of the 'United Initiatives and Movements' ('Zdruzene inicijative i pokreti') protested near the Old Sava Bridge in Belgrade - Novi Beograd against the planned project of dismantling that bridge.

On 13 October 2024, citizens staged a protest in Belgrade - Zemun to oppose the plan to demolish the 'Hotel Jugoslavija' (a symbol of Tito's Yugoslavia) and build a luxury residential and business complex.

On 11 October 2024, employees of bankrupt social enterprises protested in front of the City Hall in Nis, due to a lack of trust and dissatisfaction with the recently adopted City's Assembly program which plans out to pay unpaid salaries to these employees in four instalments, as the program does not cover interest on the unpaid wages, nor does it cover court and attorney costs.

On 11 October 2024, residents of the Block 4 protested in Belgrade - Novi Beograd, concerned that the planned construction on Pariske komune street would block sunlight and air to a nearby residential building, as well as hinder the passage of emergency services in case of an urgency.

On 8 October 2024, students from the Faculty of Political Sciences, including representatives of the student organization 'Demos', protested in front of their Faculty in Belgrade - Vozdovac against the reduction in the number of student spots for which the state pays or co-finances university fees.

On 7 October 2024, Women in Black (Zene u crnom) organized an antiwar protest in Knez Mihailova Street in Belgrade - Stari Grad, marking the anniversary of the Hamas attack, demanding a ceasefire, release of hostages, and showing support to Palestinian people in Gaza who are suffering mass human rights violations.

On 5 October 2024, a large number of citizens, organized by the group 'Support to the People of Palestine - Serbia', marched in protest from Republic Square to the German embassy and NATO Office located at the Ministry of Defense in Belgrade - Savski Venac, to show support for the Palestinian people in the response to the ongoing war and human rights violations in Gaza.

On 4 October 2024, residents of settlements around Cacak protested by blocking a local transfer station near Cacak, which had turned into an illegal garbage dump. They were concerned about their health and the poor air quality resulting from this landfill.

On 4 October 2024, employees of bankrupt social enterprises, and representatives of the Association 'Pobeda' protested in front of the City Hall in Nis because they had not been paid their wages. They additionally demanded that the state pays them interest on those unpaid wages and cover the court and attorney costs.

On 3 October 2024, farmers gathered in Backa Palanka to express solidarity with their colleagues who were negotiating with the government about their demands presented at the recent protests, which mainly concern benefits for agricultural workers. Several participants of the protest were later invited by BIA (Security Intelligence Agency) for questioning.

On 29 September 2024, around 100 farmers protested in front of the Provincial government in Novi Sad, expressing dissatisfaction with the state's neglect of the agriculture and rural areas, poor conditions and low purchase prices of agricultural products.

On 28 September 2024, around 750 kindergarten teachers (according to the Archive of public gatherings) marched in protest from Slavija Square to the Ministry of Education in Belgrade - Savski Venac, due to the decision of the Government of Serbia to withdraw its offer of a 12% salary increase and demanding better working conditions.

On 27 September 2024, employees of bankrupt social enterprises protested in Nis because they had not been paid their wages. They demanded that the authorities pay them not only their overdue wages, but also the interest on those wages. They also expressed their dissatisfaction with the announcement that they would have to sign an agreement waiving a lawsuit in order to get paid, as this would mean that they would have to cover the court and attorney costs themselves.

On 27 September 2024, citizens, organized by Together political party, gathered in the city center of Sabac and then proceeded to block a road towards Sremska Mitrovica to protest against lithium mining and the Rio Tinto company.

On 27 September 2024, a member of the Vrbas Municipal Council from the SNS political party physically assaulted a member of the 'Free Vrbas' Citizens Group, during the session of the Municipal Assembly in Vrbas, because he insisted that a journalist from KTV Zrenjanin be allowed to record the session.

Weapons seizure: On 26 September 2024, police discovered large amount of weapons, hand grenades, automatic rifles, ammunition, and explosive devices in one garage in Belgrade - Novi Beograd. Police stated that four rifles were from military sources. Investigation is ongoing to determine who is the owner of the weapons.

On 23 September 2024, citizens organized by the informal group 'Mirijevo Green and Healthy' protested in Mirijevo in Belgrade - Zvezdara against the planned cutting of 66 hectares of forest near the 'Bajdina' area for to the construction of residential and commercial buildings. The protest was interrupted by individuals claiming to be owners of the plot, who attempted to interrupt the demonstration. The police we called to re-established order and identified those who attempted to interrupt the gathering

It is suspected that the director of the European Affairs Fund of Vojvodina was among the members of this private security, acting as their chief. As a result, two students were injured, the President of PSG Youth in Novi Sad and an activist of an informal group called STAV (Students Against Authoritarian Government). Both were admitted to the ER.

notes: On 1 September 2024, around 4,000 citizens (according to the Archive of Public Gathering) protested in front of the national radio and television station (RTS) in Belgrade - Palilula against mass arrests of activists that followed the protests against lithium mining across Serbia, demanding that the RTS truthfully reports on the arrests and invite the arrested activists to tell their side of the story on live TV. The protest was organized by the Eco Guard.

notes: On 31 August 2024, citizens, including a councilor in the Assembly of the municipality of Zemun from the NKPJ political party, staged a protest in front of the 'Hotel Jugoslavija' in Belgrade - Zemun, organized by the initiative 'Fight for Zemun', to oppose the plan to demolish this hotel (a symbol of Tito's Yugoslavia) and build a luxury residential and business complex.

On 30 August 2024, about 20 activists, including a former member of Belgrade's City Assembly, an activist from the Eco Guard, and an activist from 'Blokovi 61-64', organized an initiative to protest against the demolition of the Old Sava Bridge in Belgrade - Novi Beograd, by arranging flowers, balloons and banners with the message 'The bridge is staying' on the tram that crosses the bridge, and took a round trip on that tram.

On 28 August 2024, citizens, including the local activists and representatives of the Committee Group 'Slozno za Priboj', protested on the main square in Priboj (Raska) against lithium mining in Serbia.

On 27 August 2024, a group of activists, including the President of NUNS (Independent Association of Journalists of Serbia) and representatives of the Democratic Party, organized by the Russian Democratic Society, staged a protest in front of the Appellate Court in Belgrade - Savski Venac against the possible extradition of Belarusian activist and journalist who has been in custody in Serbia for over 7 months.

Property destruction: On 27 August 2024, an unidentified person or persons started a fire in the house of the chairman of the City Committee of the 'New Face of Serbia' political party in Cacak. He and his family members managed to put out the fire before anyone was injured. A month ago, he also received a threatening message written on the street in front of his house urging him to leave politics and stop opposing lithium mining.

Defusal: On 25 August 2024, the Special Unit of Belgrade's Police removed and destroyed two hand grenades from unused premises in Daniciceva Street in Kragujevac. The person who planted the grenades, and the motive behind it remains unknown.

assoc_actor_1: Ecological Uprising; SEOS: Association of Ecological Organizations of Serbia

Property destruction: On 22 August 2024, an unidentified individual or individuals vandalized the premises of the City Council of the ruling SNS political party in Belgrade - Cukarica, by throwing stones and breaking windows. No one was injured.

On 20 August 2024, a group of citizens 'Let's save Gardos and Zemun' ('Sacuvajmo Gardos I Zemun') organized a protest in Belgrade - Zemun against the cutting of healthy trees that they claim is taking place during the reconstruction project of five streets in the center of Zemun.

On 19 August 2024, two mothers and their children started their protest walk from Backa Palanka to Belgrade to draw attention to the construction delays of a care center for children with developmental disabilities in Backa Palanka. On 12 August 2024, several hundred citizens, including a representative of the Party for Democratic Action and students, protested in Bujanovac, demanding greater respect of language rights of Albanian ethnic community in Serbia, recognition of diplomas obtained from Kosovo universities, and greater presence of Albanians in state institutions. The protest was organized by the National Albanian Council. The protest was initiated after 6000 residence addresses of Albanians were deactivated in the Presevo valley.

On 12 August 2024, during a celebration to welcome the Serbian Olympic champions in the city center of Belgrade - Stari Grad, some people including activists from the 'Start-Change' movement were holding banners and shouting slogans against 'Rio Tinto' company and exploitation of lithium in Serbia. The police intervened and arrested three activists from the 'Start-Change' movement who were released later that night.

On 11 August 2024, tens of citizens, including members of the 'Ne damo djedovinu' association and the 'ProBudimo Cacak' oppositional group, protested in Cacak, demanding the release of activists who had been detained during protests against lithium mining and 'Rio Tinto' in Belgrade.

assoc_actor_1: SEOS: Association of Ecological Organizations of Serbia
notes: On 11 August 2024, after being dispersed by the police for obstructing the railway station in Novi Beograd, demonstrators continued their protest in Pionirski Park in Belgrade - Stari Grad. Tens of citizens and activists, including representatives of 'Ne damo Jadar', then went to protest in front of the main Police Station in Belgrade - Palilula where the activists arrested the day before were being held. Between 200 and 300 people, including representatives of 'Ne damo Jadar' and 'Svice' then proceeded with their protest in front of the Government of Serbia in Belgrade - Savski Venac demanding the release of the detained activists. The protesters blocked the intersection in front of the Government's building. The initial court verdict to sentence the three arrested activists to prison was later evoked, while another activist was released after a hearing with the police.

On 11 August 2024, protesters gathered in front of the Prosecutor's office in Valjevo to oppose the trial of an activist previously arrested for participating in demonstrations against the lithium and boron exploitation.

assoc_actor_1: Police Forces of Serbia (2017-) Security Intelligence Agency

source: BETA; Danas; N1TV Online - Bosnia and Herzegovina
notes: Around 11 August 2024 (week of), multiple arrests occurred in Belgrade, Valjevo, Subotica, and Uzice (coded to Belgrade) ahead and following the protests against the lithium mine in Serbia. Prior to the protests, police in collaboration with the security intelligence agency (BIA) detained four individuals in Subotica on suspicion of planning an attack on police during the Belgrade protest. Serbian police reported that they had detained 14 people accused of committing criminal acts and behaving violently during the Belgrade protest. Start-Change movement reported that over 40 activists were detained or invited for an 'informative interview with the police' either for participating in or organizing the protests, including one pregnant former activist that was being held for several hours in the police station. Additionally, the police stated that all individuals involved in blocking the international railway stations would be identified and punished.

On 10 August 2024, citizens and activists, organized by 'Zdruzene inicijative i pokreti', protested near the Old Sava bridge in Belgrade - Novi Beograd, against the planned project of dismantling that bridge.

assoc_actor_1: SEOS: Association of Ecological Organizations of Serbia
source: BETA; FoNet; N1TV Online - Bosnia and Herzegovina
notes: On 10 August 2024, citizens and activists protested in Belgrade against the exploitation of lithium and boron in Serbia and the planned construction of the Rio Tinto lithium mine in Serbia's northwestern Jadar Valley. The protest began at Terazije in Belgrade - Stari Grad. Tens of 'Dostojni Srbije' far-right association representatives counter-protested. The crowd then split into 3 groups: one blocked the railway station Prokop in Belgrade - Savski Venac, the second group of 50 demonstrators blocked the railway station in Belgrade - Novi Beograd, while the third group blocked the highway near Gazela bridge (coded separately). Both groups that were blocking the railway stations were dispersed by the police early in the morning. Among those blocking the Prokop station were representatives of the 'Borba' organization, while the 'Ne damo Jadar' organization claims that the Special Anti-Terrorist Unit (SAJ) was the group that intervened. Three activists were arrested during this intervention. The Start-Change movement estimated that there were 119.000 protesters, 'Archive of public meetings' said there were around 40.000 people, while AFP and N1 reported 'tens of thousands', and the AP and Guardian reported 'thousands'. The police estimated the crowd to be between 25.000 and 27.000 people. The protest was organized by the association of local environmental organizations SEOS, and the issue around lithium mining sparked nationwide protests throughout Serbia. Two organizers from the 'Ne damo Jadar' initiative were later invited for an 'informative interview' by the Serbian Security Intelligence Agency. Several thousands of protesters also gathered in Terazije to and blocked the highway near the Gazela bridge in Belgrade - Novi Beograd. One driver struck protesters with his car, injuring at least two people, one of which was transferred to the ER.

On 9 August 2024, Serbian Interior Minister Ivica Dacic announced that four individuals who were allegedly planning to attack policemen and incite violence at the upcoming anti-Rio Tinto protest in Belgrade were arrested in Subotica. According to Dacic, the arrests were made based on messages the Serbian Intelligence Agency had intercepted between the arrested individuals and that their case was now being handled by the prosecution.

source: FoNet; N1TV Online - Bosnia and Herzegovina
notes: On 9 August 2024, 3.400 residents of Cacak (according to Archive of public meetings) protested against the planned construction of the Rio Tinto lithium mine in Serbia's northwestern Jadar Valley, which has ignited nation-wide protests as protesters oppose a project they believe will pollute its lush surroundings and water supply. The project is backed by the EU as the bloc tries to compete with China's supply of lithium for the production of electronic vehicles.

On 6 August 2024, residents of Indija protested against the planned construction of the Rio Tinto lithium mine in Serbia's northwestern Jadar Valley, which has ignited nation-wide protests as protesters oppose a project they believe will pollute its lush surroundings and water supply. The project is backed by the EU as the bloc tries to compete with China's supply of lithium for the production of electronic vehicles.

On 6 August 2024, a migrant from Morocco was arrested along the Nisava river near Pirot. While being escorted to the police station, he was struck by the police officers using batons. Upon arrival at the station, he was assaulted again, while his personal belongings, including his money, were confiscated. The police officers also destroyed his phone, cut his credit card with scissors, and then directed him to cross the Bulgarian border.

On 27 July 2024, a Muslim Askali (Roma) family was assaulted and their car was damaged in Novi Sad. The victim reported the perpetrators approached in a car with Serbian identification marks and mentioned the Quran.

On 26 July 2024, citizens and activists protested in Negotin against the waste disposal site, which has been continuously burning for weeks. The protesters also voiced their support to the Serbian citizens protesting against the lithium extraction.
On 25 July 2024, citizens and activists protested in Loznica against the adoption of a spatial plan that would lead to the commencement of the Rio Tinto lithium extraction project.

On 22 July 2024, around 2,5000 citizens and activists gathered in Valjevo to voice their dissent with the revival of the Rio Tinto lithium extraction project in Serbia. The protesters urged the authorities to halt the planned activities for the sake of Serbian citizens and warned about the ecological ramifications of this megalomanic project.

On 19 July 2024, over a hundred citizens and civil society activists, including one city council representative, protested in Topola against the water restrictions. Many citizens were left without water for more than 24 hours, and the protesters voiced the unbearable situation during the heatwave.

On 18 July 2024, a Kosovo citizen shot and killed a police officer during a vehicle inspection at a checkpoint in Loznica. The attacker escaped the crime scene, and while the motives remain unclear, the attacker is known for killing a KFOR soldier in 2000 as a KLA member and has strong nationalist sentiments. He was in prison in Kosovo for the 2000 killing and had escaped when he encountered Serbian police. The attacker was killed in a shoot-out with police several days later.
On 15 July 2024, citizens protested in Vrcin against the water supply cut-offs, especially stressing the importance of having water access during the heatwave.

assoc_actor_1: Ecological Uprising; SEOS: Association of Ecological Organizations of Serbia
notes: On 11 July 2024, citizens and ecological activists, including Ecological Uprising and SEOS representatives protested in front of the Serbian Constitutional Court in Belgrade - Savski Venac against Rio Tinto's lithium extraction project which has been revived by the government.

On 11 July 2024, several tens of Chetniks and other far-right supporters gathered in Novi Sad, glorifying the crimes against humanity and protesting against the Srebrenica commemoration. A group of citizens gathered to protest against propagating fascist ideologies. After a brief and minor physical and some verbal altercations, police had to separate the two groups to prevent a physical altercation.

On 10 July 2024, several tens of Women in Black representatives protested in Belgrade - Stari Grad, commemorating the anniversary of the Srebrenica genocide and calling for the Serbian authorities to accept the United Nations resolution on the Srebrenica genocide.
On 7 July 2024, citizens and ecological activists protested in Bavaniste against illegal deforestation.

On 7 July 2024, citizens protested in Belgrade - Novi Beograd against demolishing the Old Sava bridge, which is among the cultural and infrastructural heritage sites. The city's mayor is leading the initiative to replace this bridge with a modern and larger bridge.

On 6 July 2024, XR activists protested in front of the Dutch Embassy in Belgrade - Novi Beograd, voicing their support with the Dutch activists in their plea to stop subsidizing fossil fuels year after year with increasing amounts.

On 1 July 2024, students blocked the entrance of the University of Novi Sad rectorate in Novi Sad, demanding a change of rules for Student Parliament elections, which is currently discriminatory as students from different faculties cannot apply.
On 29 June 2024, around a hundred cyclists passed the bridge in Belgrade - Novi Beograd, protesting against the abolition of the yellow lane for public transport.

assoc_actor_2: Government of Israel (2022-); Police Forces of Serbia (2017-)

Prior to the attack the perpetrator filmed a video threatening Jews, Christians, and atheists. The policeman had the arrow taken from his neck and was in a stable condition.

On 28 June 2024, residents of the settlement Delijski vis in Nis staged a and blocked the crossroad between Marina Drzica and Svrljiski partizanski odred streets in Nis (Nis-Medijana), demanding from the local authorities to pave the streets in their neighborhood, which would prevent the floods that they face every time after heavy rains.
On 28 June 2024, between 100 and 200 residents protested in Belgrade - Vozdovac, demanding an urgent reaction from the authorities on the massive flooding of their residential areas.
